gmd:title.gco:CharacterString: Ensemble Prediction System-Bias Correction ( EPS-BC ) Tropical Cyclone Tracks

gmd:abstract.gco:CharacterString:
The use of ensemble weather models such as the European Centre for Medium-Range Weather Forecasts (ECMWF) Ensemble Prediction System (EPS) provides a range of probabilistic outcomes which better align with planning and risk management assessments. An automated procedure to bias correct 10 day tropical cyclone forecasts generated by the ECMWF-EPS forecast system has been developed and fully operationalised under the name Ensemble Prediction System Bias Corrector (EPS-BC). This system ensures clients are able to make critical business decisions based on probabilistic forecasts that better represent the natural variability of tropical cyclones across the northwest shelf. Ensemble Prediction System-Bias Corrector (EPS-BC) tropical cyclone track data are now available as an outcome of a Joint Industry Project for Tropical Cyclone Research and companion operationalisation project.
The EPS -BC procedure does the following: 1 Detects tropical cyclones in the ECMWF-EPS 2 Corrects the tropical cyclone properties for systematic bias 3 Inserts a new vortex, constructed to have the bias corrected properties, over the existing vortex in the model fields 4 The new model fields are used as input to further tasks The EPS-BC uses a multivariate linear regression method to bias correct storm intensity and structure. The system performs bias correction based on data from the previous two seasons.
The fix location of tropical disturbances at a specific time are derived from gridded output from the ECMWF-EPS. The associated values of these disturbances (fixes) notably, maximum wind speeds, central pressure and gale radii may be bias corrected.
The data from EPS-BC has the following attributes:
disturbance_id and cyclone_name: identifiers which group disturbances of the different ensemble members ensemble_no: ECMWF EPS has 51 ensemble members. Each member can generate a tropical cyclone track fix_hour: number of hours since base time (model run) latitude / longitude: position of minimum Mean Sea Level Pressure (MSLP) of the fix. Coodinates are only to 1 decimal place max_wind_spd_msp / kn: maximum 10 minute mean of the wind speed at a height of 10 metres near the fix, possibly bias corrected. Available in units of metres per second and knots. central_pres_hpa: minimum pressure in hectopascals near the centre of system, possibly bias corrected. radius_gf_wind_nmi: radius in nautical miles from the system centre to the outer extent of gales (greater than 34 knots). Although, there are fields for each of the four quadrants (NE, NW, SE, SW), EPS_BC currently only generates one value. Radius possibly bias corrected.
The fix locations are unmodified from the original ECMWF EPS track data.
Using the above values, points (fixes), lines (tracks) and polygons (gale radii) are created and used as the source of the Web Map Service (WMS) and Web Feature Service (WFS).

gmd:purpose.gco:CharacterString: To show Ensemble Prediction System-Bias Correction (EPS-BC) Tropical Cyclone Tracks.

gmd:maintenanceNote.gco:CharacterString: The model is run twice daily for basetimes of 00 UTC and 12 UTC during the tropical cyclone season (November to April). The data are not available until approximately 8:40 UTC and 20:40 UTC. Technical difficulties may further delay the output.

gmd:keyword.gco:CharacterString: EARTH SCIENCE | Atmosphere | Atmospheric Phenomena | Cyclones

The fix, lines and radii are the basis for the WMS/WFS.

gmd:title.gco:CharacterString: ACORN-SAT ( Australian Climate Observations Reference Network - Surface Air Temperature ) - Australia. v.2 (1910 onwards)

gmd:alternateTitle.gco:CharacterString: Australian Climate Observations Reference Network – Surface Air Temperature ( ACORN-SAT ) v.2 {DRAFT stopgap metadata} ACORNSAT

gmd:abstract.gco:CharacterString:
The Australian Climate Observations Reference Network - Surface Air Temperature (ACORN-SAT) dataset v.2 is comprised of a consistent - or homogeneous - daily temperature record over a 105 year time-range, for 112 observation locations across Australia. This dataset aims to create a modern Australian temperature record, by selecting relevant sites which have a long data timespan, and maximise network coverage across the continent.
This data was released in December 2018, and supercedes the ACORN-SAT v.1 dataset. (see : http://www.bom.gov.au/metadata/19115/ANZCW0503900450 ). New data is being added incrementally to this v.2 dataset. A snapshot of 1910 to 2018-12 will soon be made available.

gmd:purpose.gco:CharacterString: The Australian Climate Observations Reference Network – Surface Air Temperature (ACORN-SAT) dataset series has been developed to monitor climate variability and change in Australia.

gmd:alternateTitle.gco:CharacterString: High Seas Forecast Area Boundaries

gmd:abstract.gco:CharacterString: For shipping, the Bureau of Meteorology issues regular forecasts and warnings for High Seas Forecast Areas. These forecast areas represent sub-divisions of Australia's responsibility for providing Maritime Safety Information (MSI) for METAREA X, as part of the IMO/WMO Worldwide Met-Ocean Information and Warning Service (WWMIWS). This dataset shows the delineation of these boundaries.

gmd:purpose.gco:CharacterString: To show the High Seas Forecast Areas.

gmd:statement.gco:CharacterString:
Sites extracted from SitesDB database and converted into a shapefile.
In December 2017, two new forecast sites were added in NSW, Mirrool Creek at East Mirrool Regulator and Aberdeen.
In April 2018, one new forecast site was added in Victoria, Tambo River D/S Ramrod Creek.
In May 2018, three new forecast sites were added in Victoria: Cann River (West) at Weeragua, Cann River (East) at Chandlers Creek and Genoa River at The Gorge. In South Australia, one new forecast site was added, Bremer River at Langhorne Creek.
In September 2018, one new forecast site was added in Northern Territory: Katherine River at Katherine Bridge.
In October 2018, three new forecast sites were added in NSW: Tweed River at Tumbulgum, Hawkesbury River at North Richmond and Hawkesbury River at Windsor. The latter two replace the old forecast sites of North Richmond Bridge and Hawkesbury River at Windsor Bridge. There was a small name change for two sites. Tweed River at Chinderah (Barney's Point) (AHD) to Tweed River at Chinderah (Barney's Point) and Tweed River at Murwillumbah (AHD) to Tweed River at North Murwillumbah.
In December 2018, a new forecast site was added in Qld: Mooloolah River at Palmview. In NSW, Tweed River at Tumbulgum (AHD) was renamed to Tweed River at Tumbulgum.
In February 2019, a site name was changed in Qld: Cooper Creek at Windorah to Cooper Creek at Windorah (Long Crossing).

gmd:abstract.gco:CharacterString:
Flood Warning Catchments for Australia. Flood Warnings for the areas delineated by these boundaries are issued by the Bureau of Meteorology when required.
The catchment and sub-catchment boundaries have been defined using the Geofabric toolset. As the catchments have been derived from a digital elevation model, the boundaries have jagged edges and gaps caused by sinks. See http://www.bom.gov.au/water/geofabric/index.shtml for more information.
Please note catchments are only delineated in areas where flood warnings are produced.

gmd:purpose.gco:CharacterString: To show the Flood Warning Catchments.

gmd:keyword.gco:CharacterString: EARTH SCIENCE | HUMAN DIMENSIONS | BOUNDARIES | ADMINISTRATIVE DIVISIONS
EARTH SCIENCE SERVICES | ENVIRONMENTAL ADVISORIES | HYDROLOGICAL ADVISORIES | FLOODS | BOUNDARIES

gmd:statement.gco:CharacterString:
Catchment and sub-catchment boundaries have been defined primarily using the Geofabric toolset. See http://www.bom.gov.au/water/geofabric/index.shtml. In some areas, other boundaries have been used, for example Australian Water Resource Council (AWRC) river basins.
In March 2017, one new subcatchment (Macdonald River) was defined for the Hawkesbury and Nepean River catchment and two for the Lachlan River (Lower Lachlan River downstream of Jemalong Weir to Euabalong, Lower Lachlan River downstream of Jemalong Weir to Euabalong). Four new sub catchments were created for Murrumbidgee River (Murrumbidgee River to Burrinjuck Dam, Murrumbidgee River downstream of Narrandera to Darlington Point, Murrumbidgee River downstream of Wagga Wagga to Narrandera, Billabong and Yanco Creeks). The names of several catchments/subcatchments were changed to be more descriptive.
In April 2017, five new subcatchments were defined for the Barwon and Darling River Catchment in NSW (Darling River downstream of Tilpa to Wilcannia, Darling River downstream of Bourke to Tilpa, Barwon and Darling Rivers downstream of Brewarrina to Bourke, Barwon River downstream of Walgett to Brewarrina). In Victoria, two new subcatchments were defined for Wimmera River (Natimuk Creek, Avon-Richardson Rivers). Two new subcatchments were created for Loddon River (Bendigo and Bullock Creeks, Loddon River downstream of Kerang). Three new subcatchments were defined for Cann and Genoa River (Bemm River, Cann River and Genoa River). In addition, there were some name changes.
In June 2017, some minor changes to boundaries were done in SA, VIC and QLD.
In July 2017, there were four new subcatchments added in South Australia, namely two in Murray River SA Section (River Murray, Lower River Murray) and two in Inland Rivers SA (Warbuton, Cooper Creek).
In August 2017, the catchment boundaries for Parramatta and Cooks River in NSW were refined.
In September 2017, three new subcatchments were added in NSW. One in each of the Hawkesbury and Nepean Rivers (Upper Coxs River), Murrumbidgee River (Upper Murrumbidgee) and Hunter River (Newcastle Area).
In October 2017, three new catchments were added in WA namely Sturt Creek, Salt Lakes, Sandy Desert and Warburton. Plus the catchments of East Kimberley, Goldfields and Interior were removed.
In November 2017, a new catchment was added in WA (Yarra Yarra Lakes District). Three new subcatchments were created for the Glenelg Catchment. They were Glenelg River to Casterton, Glenelg River downstream of Casterton and Wannon River.
In December 2017, a new catchment was added in NSW (Mirrool Creek) with three new subcatchments of Sandy Creek, Upper Mirrool Creek and Mirrool Creek to East Mirrool Creek Regulator.
In April 2018, the Tambo River Catchment in Victoria was split into two subcatchments, namely Nicholson River and Tambo River. The catchment was renamed Tambo and Nicholson River.
In February 2019, a change in boundary for Goulburn River subcatchment in Victoria. Whiteheads Creek catchment is included in "Goulburn River Lake Eildon to Seymour sub-catchment"

gmd:alternateTitle.gco:CharacterString: Ocean Wind Warning Boundaries

gmd:abstract.gco:CharacterString:
This dataset shows the delineation of METAREA X Ocean Wind Warning region boundaries (WESTERN, NORTHERN, NORTH EAST, SOUTHERN and SOUTH EAST).
Ocean Wind Warnings are prepared by the Bureau of Meteorology, as part of the IMO/WMO Worldwide Met-Ocean Information and Warning Service (WWMIWS) for mariners in the Australian high seas region, METAREA X.

gmd:purpose.gco:CharacterString: To show the Ocean Wind Warnings Areas for METAREA X.

gmd:title.gco:CharacterString: Australian Gridded Climate Data ( AGCD ) / AWAP ; v1.0.0 Snapshot (1900-01-01 to 2018-12-31) ( not yet released )

gmd:alternateTitle.gco:CharacterString: Australian Gridded Climate Data (AGCD); Australian Water Availability Project ( AWAP ) {DRAFT stopgap metadata}

gmd:abstract.gco:CharacterString:
Gridded climate data of site-based surface observations or satellite data: - Time coverage: Site-based data are used to provide gridded climate data at the daily and monthly timescale for rainfall (1900+), maximum and minimum temperature (1910+), 9am and 3pm vapour pressure (1971+).
Spatial coverage: The data encompasses the Australian continent and Tasmania - For this dataset (delivered publicly) - the dataset is reproducible from the same starting data using the code described in the file metadata. The dataset can be cited in publications (see License details below.) Background information is available in the paper by Jones,D., Wang, W. and Fawcett, R. [2009] "High-quality spatial climate data-sets for Australia", Australian Meteorological and Oceanographic Journal, 58(4), pp.233-248; accessible from: [ http://www.bom.gov.au/amm/docs/2009/jones_hres.pdf ] or [ http://www.bom.gov.au/amm/papers.php?year=2009 ].

gmd:purpose.gco:CharacterString: The AGCD grids are produced to show the rainfall, temperature, pressure, solar exposure, and NDVI values across Australia in the form of two-dimensional arrays, using 0.05x0.05 degree grids.

gmd:maintenanceNote.gco:CharacterString: This netcdf dataset is a snapshot from the start of the timeseries (1900 to June 2017); Each snapshot is of the entire previous dataset and extends a further 6 months, superceding the preceding snapshot. The superseded snapshots will be archived once superceded, but will still be available on request.

gmd:keyword.gco:CharacterString: EARTH SCIENCE | Atmosphere | Precipitation | Liquid Precipitation | Rain
EARTH SCIENCE | Atmosphere | Atmospheric Temperature | Surface Temperature | MAXIMUM / MINIMUM TEMPERATURE
DataParam: Rainfall - totals - per day - gridded - Australia
DataParam: Temperature, air - maximum - for each day, gridded
DataParam: Temperature, air - minimum - for each day, gridded

gmd:useLimitation.gco:CharacterString: Operational dataset with snapshot of historical archive at a point in time. Limited spatial resolution (approx. 5kmx5km)

gmd:otherConstraints.gco:CharacterString: The grid data files in this AGCD Snapshot are available under the CC-BY-NC 4.0 International Licence. The CC-BY-NC 4.0 International ( Creative Commons Attribution Non-Commercial CC-BY-NC v.4.0 international ) license summary may be found here: [ https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc/4.0/ ]. The full license text may be found here: [ https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc/4.0/legalcode ]. This AGCD snapshot will be : a) freely accessible (via thredds), and b) available for registered researchers, from NCI's raijin. Data should be cited as : Australian Bureau of Meteorology (date) [Title], { https://doi.org/10.4227/166/5a8647d1c23e0 } Downloaded from [url] on [date].

gmd:supplementalInformation.gco:CharacterString: Data are individual files at the daily and monthly timescale. The time record dimension is UNLIMITED, allowing concatenation of the daily/monthly files. Limited spatial resolution (approx. 5km x 5km)
